issues.title: CA managing certificates
issues.author: danwing
issues.body:
in 5.1, it says:

> Dependency on the CA to manage a large number of certificates.

But the Certificate Authority does not manage the certificates it signs -- it signs the certificate, adds it to a certificate log, and forgets about it. 

I don't know the intent of this sentence, but can it be improved?

pulls.title: add self-signed cert, and hint at softening .local / .internal certificate handling
pulls.author: danwing

comments.body: I don't think using self-signed certificate is a good idea. It will not work with IoT devices (without User Interface) supporting Encrypted DNS forwarders.  Most importantly, it trains users to ignore certificate errors and accept certificates which is a poor security practice. Self-signed certificates will only work with DDR in opportunistic mode and it not enabled by default on clients (e.g., windows).

@tireddy2, better recoding this as part of the analysis text.

Dan's text does not recommend this and I think is fair.

self-signed certificates are included as an example of an existing -- but bad -- practice.  

However, I am unclear how an IoT device, lacking that same user interface, will work with a local CA (where that CA needs to be added to the IoT device's trust list), or work with delegated credentials (should it honor delegated credentials for cpe.danwing.example.com but not cpe.tiru.example.com and how would it know?).

Said another way: do we need a requirement that the solution work, somehow, without user interaction??  I don't know how to achieve that.  

Another point: several modern IoT devices have the ability to get their initial configuration from a smartphone (today, that is mostly just Wi-Fi password), because they lack a user interface. They could expand that capability -- if they cared -- to bootstrap trusting a local (home-installed) CA, do TOFU for DNR, or whatevs.

I added a sentence that users become accustomed to the warnings which is bad.

But I'd still like to know if there is need for IoT to get a Requirement, and how we should express that Requirement.

IoT may have specifics and may support other DNR variants such as draft-lenders-core-dnr. I tend to keep the discussion in a level that can help adoption of this draft.

The sentence you had about bad practice is good/sufficient for the analysis at this stage. IoT mention if any should be very short. Thanks.
Update looks good.

pulls.title: generalize: exchange 'CPE' with 'device' all over, and related changes
pulls.author: danwing

comments.body: I don't see any mention of the term STAR in RFC9345. You seem to have confused with https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9115.html
In case of RFC 9345, there is no additional interaction with the CA. You seem to referring to STAR defined in ACME.

reviews.author: tireddy2
reviews.body: Most of the changes look good.

comments.body:
I agree STAR is not mentioned in RFC9345.  However, RFC9345 says this in its Section 3,

> To limit exposure in case of the compromise of a delegated credential's private key, delegated credentials have a maximum validity period. In the absence of an application profile standard specifying otherwise, the **maximum validity period is set to 7 days**. 

which meets all the meaning of STAR!  

I will soften the language explaining RFC9345's recommended validity period.
RFC9345 recommends 7-day, but I guess you are expecting a system with a longer lifetime -- if so, we need to say so in this I-D.  How many days would you like?

I came up with even softer language.  Now reads:

> Delegated credentials {{?RFC9345}} allows the entity operating the CPE (e.g., vendor or ISP) to sign the CPE's public key. The frequency of CA interactions for renewals can remain the same as with normal certificates ({{normal-certificates}}), but the interactions are with the vendor's service rather than the public CA.
